Plant Disease Detector your crop Suggestion Hub Knowledge Hub Give Feedback Settings report issues You Take a Crop 1. First Click On A Take A Crop Button And Take a picture Of A Your Selected Plant. 2. After Taking Picture Of Plant you Will Get Your Plant Diagnosis Report. 3. After Analysis Diagnosis Report Get Medicine. New Post Add image send Your post title Add a title of post Description Of A Post Describe More About Post Reading List image : Article : Join The Community Give FeedBack How is Your experience with our app? We love to hear your suggestions. Category : Sort by name Sort by date Ascending Order Descending Order Enter your name Enter your phone number you all receive an SMS shortly with the verification code. Already have a account? Send verification code sign in Welcome back SIGN IN WITH GOOGLE SIGN IN WITH PHONE NUMBER sign up Do not have a account How is your experience with our app? Please describe the issue you are experiencing with this content. English Hindi Gujarati
//data-collection -> Offline Knowledge hub
Wheat Wheat thrives in cool temperate climates with a temperature range of 10°C to 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (450–650 mm per year) and can tolerate a variety of conditions but grows best in areas with well-defined seasons. Wheat grows best in well-drained, fertile loamy soils, with a slightly acidic to neutral pH between 6.0 and 7.0. The soil should have good organic content and be free of waterlogging. Rust (Puccinia spp.): This fungal disease causes orange or red pustules on leaves. It weakens the plant, reducing yields. Prevention includes using resistant wheat varieties, applying fungicides like triadimefon, rotating crops, and removing infected crop residues. Avoid planting in the same field for consecutive years to minimize the build-up of rust spores. Powdery Mildew (Blumeria graminis): This fungal disease causes white powdery spots on leaves, which can reduce photosynthesis and yield. To prevent powdery mildew, use resistant varieties, apply sulfur fungicides early in the growing season, and ensure good air circulation around the plants by spacing them properly.
Rice Rice thrives in hot, humid tropical to subtropical climates, with temperatures ranging from 25°C to 35°C. It requires high humidity and abundant water, with rainfall between 800–1500 mm per year. Rice grows best in clayey or silty soils that retain water. It needs a slightly acidic to neutral pH (5.5 to 7.5). The soil should have good water-holding capacity, and fields should be irrigated consistently. Blast (Pyricularia oryzae): A fungal disease that causes lesions on leaves, stems, and grains, leading to reduced yield. Use resistant rice varieties, apply tricyclazole fungicide, and avoid over-fertilizing. Practice crop rotation and remove infected plant debris after harvest to prevent reinfection. Bacterial Leaf Blight (Xanthomonas oryzae): This bacterial disease causes yellowing of leaves and wilting. To prevent bacterial leaf blight, use resistant varieties, plant disease-free seeds, practice crop rotation, and avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer that promotes bacterial growth. Maintain proper water management.
Maize Maize grows best in warm subtropical to tropical climates with temperatures between 18°C and 30°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–900 mm), but irrigation may be necessary in dry periods. Maize prefers fertile, well-drained loamy soils with a pH between 5.5 and 7.5. It benefits from soils rich in organic matter and good drainage. Gray Leaf Spot (Cercospora zeae-maydis): This fungal disease causes grayish lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield. Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin and mancozeb at the first sign of symptoms. Practice crop rotation, use disease-free seeds, and destroy infected crop residues to prevent reinfection. Downy Mildew (Sclerophthora rayii): A fungal disease that causes yellowing and wilting of leaves, reducing the plant\'s vitality. To prevent downy mildew, use resistant maize varieties, apply fungicides like metalaxyl, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plants and maintain proper soil drainage.
Barley Barley prefers cool temperate climates with a temperature range of 12°C to 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (350–600 mm) and grows best in areas with well-defined seasons. Barley thrives in fertile, well-drained soils, preferably sandy loam or clay loam, with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. The soil should have good fertility and moisture retention but should not be waterlogged. Leaf Rust (Puccinia hordei): This fungal disease causes orange or red pustules on barley leaves. Prevent leaf rust by using resistant barley varieties, applying fungicides like triadimefon or tebuconazole, and rotating crops to reduce pathogen buildup. Net Blotch (Pyrenophora teres): A fungal disease that creates dark spots and streaks on leaves, reducing photosynthesis. Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plant material from the field to reduce disease spread.
Millet Millet thrives in semi-arid and tropical climates, with a temperature range of 20°C to 30°C. It requires moderate rainfall (400–600 mm) and tolerates drought conditions better than many other crops. Millet grows well in light, well-drained soils, such as sandy loams and clay loams. It prefers slightly alkaline soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. Blast (Pyricularia grisea): A fungal disease causing lesions on leaves, stems, and panicles, leading to yield loss. To prevent blast, use resistant millet varieties, apply fungicides like carbendazim, and practice crop rotation. Avoid high humidity levels and wet foliage during flowering. Downy Mildew (Sclerospora graminicola): A fungal disease that causes yellowing and wilting of leaves. Apply metalaxyl fungicides and use resistant varieties. Rotate crops, avoid excess nitrogen fertilization, and remove infected plant debris after harvest.
Sorghum Sorghum grows in hot, semi-arid climates with temperatures between 25°C and 35°C. It requires moderate rainfall (400–700 mm) and can withstand drought conditions better than many other crops. Sorghum prefers well-drained, fertile soils such as loamy and sandy loam, with a pH between 5.5 and 7.5. The soil should have good moisture retention while not being waterlogged. Anthracnose (Colletotrichum sublineola): A fungal disease that causes dark lesions on leaves and stems, reducing yields. To prevent anthracnose, use resistant varieties, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, and rotate crops. Ensure proper field sanitation by removing infected plant debris. Grain Mold (Fusarium spp.): A fungal disease that causes grain discoloration and mold growth. Prevent grain mold by using resistant varieties, applying fungicides like tebuconazole, and maintaining proper field sanitation. Store grains in dry, well-ventilated conditions.
Sunflower Sunflowers grow best in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. They require full sunlight and moderate rainfall (400–800 mm per year), thriving in areas with well-defined seasons. Sunflowers prefer well-drained sandy loam or loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. Soil should be nutrient-rich and provide good drainage to avoid waterlogging. Downy Mildew (Plasmopara halstedii): A fungal disease causing yellow spots on leaves, leading to reduced photosynthesis and yield. Prevent downy mildew by using resistant sunflower varieties, applying fungicides like metalaxyl, and practicing crop rotation. Remove infected plant debris from the field after harvest. Sclerotinia (White Mold): A fungal disease that causes white fluffy growths on the stem and leaves, reducing seed quality. To prevent Sclerotinia, apply fungicides like boscalid, rotate crops, and remove infected plants from the field. Maintain good airflow between plants to reduce humidity.
Potato Potatoes thrive in cool climates with temperatures between 15°C and 20°C. They require moderate rainfall (450–800 mm per year) and a frost-free growing season. Potatoes prefer well-drained, fertile sandy loam soils with a pH of 5.5 to 6.5. Soil should have high organic matter content to ensure proper tuber development. Late Blight (Phytophthora infestans): A fungal disease that causes dark lesions on leaves and stems, leading to crop failure. Prevent late blight by applying fungicides such as copper-based products, ensuring proper spacing for airflow, and removing infected leaves and plants promptly. Rotate crops and avoid excessive nitrogen use. Early Blight (Alternaria solani): A fungal disease that causes dark brown spots on leaves, affecting the plant’s ability to photosynthesize. To prevent early blight, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil and practice crop rotation. Ensure that plants are not overcrowded to allow for proper airflow and avoid over-irrigating.
Cucumber Cucumbers thrive in warm temperatures between 20°C and 30°C and require a lot of sunlight. They need moderate rainfall (600–800 mm per year) or regular irrigation. Cucumbers grow best in loamy, well-drained soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good moisture retention properties. Powdery Mildew (Sphaerotheca fuliginea): A fungal disease causing a white, powdery coating on leaves and stems. Apply sulfur-based fungicides or neem oil, remove infected leaves, and ensure proper spacing to promote air circulation around plants. Avoid wetting foliage during watering. Downy Mildew (Pseudoperonospora cubensis): A fungal disease that causes yellow spots on leaves and eventually leads to plant death. To prevent downy mildew, use resistant varieties, apply fungicides such as mancozeb or metalaxyl, and practice crop rotation. Keep the garden free of infected plant material.
Lettuce Lettuce grows best in cool temperate climates with temperatures ranging from 10°C to 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) or regular irrigation. Lettuce prefers well-drained, fertile sandy loam or clay loam soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter and capable of retaining moisture. Downy Mildew (Bremia lactucae): A fungal disease that causes yellowing of leaves and mold growth on the underside of leaves. To prevent downy mildew, apply fungicides such as metalaxyl, remove infected leaves, and avoid overcrowding. Ensure proper spacing and good air circulation. Leaf Spot (Cercospora spp.): A fungal disease that causes dark, circular lesions on leaves, reducing their quality. Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper sulfate, and practice crop rotation. Remove diseased leaves and avoid over-watering or wetting the leaves during irrigation.
Tomato Tomatoes thrive in warm climates with temperatures ranging from 20°C to 30°C. They require full sun and moderate rainfall (600–800 mm per year). Tomatoes grow best in well-drained, fertile loamy soils with a pH between 6.0 and 6.8. Soil should be rich in organic matter to promote healthy growth. Late Blight (Phytophthora infestans): A fungal disease that causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems. Apply copper-based fungicides and practice good crop rotation. Remove infected leaves promptly and avoid wetting foliage when watering. Provide adequate spacing for good airflow. Tomato Mosaic Virus (TMV): A viral disease that causes mosaic-like patterns on leaves, stunting plant growth. Use resistant tomato varieties, avoid handling plants when wet, and disinfect tools regularly. Remove infected plants from the garden and prevent aphids and other insect vectors.
Carrot Carrots grow best in cooler climates with temperatures between 15°C and 20°C. They require moderate rainfall (400–600 mm per year) or irrigation. Carrots thrive in well-drained, loose sandy loam or loamy soils with a pH of 6.0 to 7.0. The soil should be free from stones and clods to allow proper root formation. Alternaria Leaf Blight (Alternaria dauci): A fungal disease causing dark lesions on leaves, leading to reduced photosynthesis and yield. Apply fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil, remove infected leaves, and practice crop rotation. Ensure adequate soil drainage and avoid overcrowding. Root-Knot Nematodes (Meloidogyne spp.): Nematodes that cause root swelling and deformities, reducing root quality. Use resistant carrot varieties, apply nematicides if necessary, and practice crop rotation with non-host plants to reduce nematode populations in the soil.
Sugarcane Sugarcane thrives in tropical climates with temperatures between 25°C and 35°C. It requires high humidity and abundant rainfall (1500–2500 mm per year), though it can tolerate drought conditions when well-established. Sugarcane grows best in deep, fertile loamy soils with good drainage and a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good water-holding capacity. Red Rot (Colletotrichum falcatum): A fungal disease causing a reddish-brown discoloration in the stalks, which can lead to reduced sugar content. Use resistant sugarcane varieties, practice crop rotation, and remove infected plants. Apply fungicides and ensure proper irrigation to prevent water stress. Smut (Ustilago scitaminea): A fungal disease that causes deformed shoots and decreases yield. Use disease-free planting material, apply fungicides, and remove infected plants. Practice crop rotation and maintain good field hygiene to reduce the spread of the disease.
Spinach Spinach grows best in cool climates with temperatures ranging from 10°C to 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) or irrigation throughout the growing season. Spinach thrives in fertile, well-drained loamy soils with a pH of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter, which helps retain moisture and nutrients. Downy Mildew (Peronospora farinosa): A fungal disease that causes yellowing of leaves and the appearance of fuzzy growth on the undersides of leaves. Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides like copper sulfate, and remove infected plants. Ensure proper air circulation and avoid excessive moisture on leaves. Powdery Mildew (Erysiphe cichoracearum): A fungal disease that appears as a white, powdery growth on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield. To prevent powdery mildew, apply sulfur-based fungicides, remove infected plant material, and space plants to allow good airflow. Avoid overhead irrigation.
Pea Peas thrive in cool, temperate climates with temperatures between 10°C and 20°C. They require moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) or irrigation during the growing season. Peas grow best in well-drained, fertile loamy soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5. The soil should have good moisture retention while being well-aerated. Powdery Mildew (Erysiphe pisi): A fungal disease causing white, powdery growth on leaves, stems, and pods, reducing plant vigor and yield. Apply sulfur-based fungicides, remove infected plant parts, and ensure proper spacing between plants for good airflow. Avoid high humidity and wet conditions. Root Rot (Aphanomyces euteiches): A fungal disease that causes wilting, yellowing, and decay of roots. Use resistant pea varieties, avoid over-watering, and ensure well-drained soil. Practice crop rotation and remove infected plant material to prevent the spread of the fungus.
Onion Onions thrive in temperate climates with temperatures between 13°C and 24°C. They require moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) and benefit from long daylight hours. Onions grow best in well-drained, loose sandy loam soils with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter and allow for good root development. Downy Mildew (Peronospora destructor): A fungal disease that causes yellowing of leaves and stunted growth, reducing bulb quality. Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides such as copper-based products, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plant material from the field to reduce disease spread. White Rot (Sclerotium cepivorum): A fungal disease that causes rot at the base of the onion bulb and produces white, fluffy mycelium. Practice crop rotation with non-allium crops, use disease-free planting material, and apply fungicides like thiophanate-methyl. Ensure proper drainage to avoid excess moisture around the bulbs.
Garlic Garlic grows best in temperate climates with temperatures between 12°C and 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) or regular irrigation. Garlic prefers well-drained, loose, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter and well-aerated to allow proper root development. Rust (Puccinia allii): A fungal disease that causes orange or red pustules on leaves, leading to yellowing and premature death of leaves. Use resistant garlic varieties, apply fungicides such as mancozeb, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plant material and avoid planting garlic in the same area for consecutive years. White Rot (Sclerotium cepivorum): A fungal disease that affects garlic bulbs, causing decay and white fungal growth at the base of the plant. Rotate crops with non-allium crops, avoid over-watering, and use disease-free seed garlic. Apply appropriate fungicides and remove infected bulbs from the field immediately.
Eggplant Eggplant thrives in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. It requires full sun and moderate rainfall (600–900 mm) throughout the growing season. Eggplant prefers well-drained, fertile loamy soils with a pH range of 5.5 to 6.8. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good drainage to prevent root rot. Fusarium Wilt (Fusarium oxysporum): A soil-borne fungal disease that causes yellowing of leaves, wilting, and eventually plant death. Use resistant eggplant varieties, practice crop rotation, and avoid excessive watering. Remove infected plants and apply appropriate fungicides like thiophanate-methyl. Aphid-Transmitted Viruses (Tomato mosaic virus, etc.): Aphids can spread various viral diseases that cause leaf deformation, stunted growth, and reduced yields. Control aphids with insecticides such as neem oil or insecticidal soap, and practice good field hygiene. Use virus-free seeds and remove infected plants from the field immediately.
Bell Pepper Bell peppers grow best in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. They require moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) and plenty of sunlight. Bell peppers prefer well-drained, fertile loamy soils with a pH between 6.0 and 6.8. The soil should be rich in organic matter and well-aerated to promote healthy root growth. Blossom End Rot (Calcium Deficiency): A physiological disorder that causes dark, sunken spots at the blossom end of the fruit. Ensure consistent watering and avoid irregular watering. Apply calcium nitrate fertilizer to maintain proper calcium levels in the soil. Bacterial Spot (Xanthomonas vesicatoria): A bacterial disease that causes water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit, leading to plant defoliation and yield reduction. Use resistant varieties, apply copper-based bactericides, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plant material and avoid overhead irrigation to minimize spread.
Cabbage Cabbage grows best in cool climates with temperatures between 15°C and 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) or irrigation throughout the growing season. Cabbage prefers well-drained, fertile soils rich in organic matter, with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be loose to allow for good root development. Clubroot (Plasmodiophora brassicae): A soil-borne fungal disease that causes swollen, distorted roots, leading to stunted growth and reduced yield. Practice crop rotation with non-brassica crops, apply lime to raise soil pH, and remove infected plants. Use resistant cabbage varieties when available. Aphid Infestation (Various species): Aphids can transmit viral diseases, weaken plants, and cause stunted growth. Control aphids using insecticidal soap or neem oil, and practice good field hygiene. Avoid planting cabbage in fields where aphids have previously been a problem.
Broccoli Broccoli grows best in cool climates with temperatures between 15°C and 20°C. It requires moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) or irrigation throughout the growing season. Broccoli prefers fertile, well-drained loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should have high organic matter content to promote healthy growth. Downy Mildew (Peronospora brassicae): A fungal disease that causes yellowing of leaves and stunted growth. Apply copper-based fungicides, ensure proper air circulation, and remove infected plants. Avoid overcrowding and irrigating overhead. Cabbage Worm (Pieris rapae): A pest that feeds on broccoli leaves, leading to reduced yield and quality. Use insecticidal soap or neem oil to control cabbage worms, and practice crop rotation. Cover plants with row covers to prevent insect infestation.
Cauliflower Cauliflower thrives in cool climates with temperatures between 15°C and 20°C. It requires regular rainfall or irrigation (500–800 mm) during the growing season. Cauliflower prefers well-drained, fertile, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter to support healthy growth and yield. Black Rot (Xanthomonas campestris): A bacterial disease that causes yellowing and wilting of leaves, often starting from the margins. Use disease-resistant varieties, apply copper-based bactericides, and practice crop rotation. Avoid overhead irrigation and remove infected plants to reduce bacterial spread. Downy Mildew (Peronospora parasitica): A fungal disease that results in yellow patches on leaves and stunted growth. Apply fungicides like copper sulfate, ensure proper spacing for good airflow, and remove infected plant material. Avoid wetting the leaves during irrigation.
Zucchini Zucchini grows best in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. It needs plenty of sunlight and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) throughout the growing season. Zucchini thrives in well-drained, fertile, loamy soils with a pH of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should have good moisture retention without becoming waterlogged. Powdery Mildew (Podosphaera xanthii): A fungal disease characterized by white, powdery spots on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield. Apply sulfur-based fungicides, remove infected leaves, and space plants properly for good airflow. Avoid wetting foliage and practice crop rotation to prevent fungal buildup. Squash Bug (Anasa tristis): A pest that feeds on plant sap, causing wilting, yellowing, and early fruit drop. Control squash bugs with insecticides like neem oil or pyrethrins, and manually remove them. Practice good field hygiene and use row covers to protect plants.
Pumpkin Pumpkins grow best in warm climates with temperatures between 18°C and 25°C. They require full sunlight and moderate rainfall (600–800 mm) throughout the growing season. Pumpkins prefer well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 6.8. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good moisture retention for optimal growth. Powdery Mildew (Podosphaera xanthii): A fungal disease causing white, powdery growth on leaves and stems, which reduces photosynthesis. Use sulfur-based fungicides, provide proper spacing between plants for airflow, and avoid watering overhead. Remove infected leaves immediately. Cucumber Beetle (Acalymma vittatum): A pest that feeds on pumpkin vines and leaves, leading to damage and disease transmission. Control cucumber beetles with insecticides or natural predators like ladybugs, and use row covers to protect the plants from pests.
Sweet Corn Sweet corn grows best in warm climates with temperatures between 18°C and 30°C. It requires full sunlight and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) or irrigation throughout the growing season. Sweet corn prefers well-drained, fertile, loamy soils with a pH range of 5.8 to 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good water retention without being soggy. Corn Smut (Ustilago maydis): A fungal disease that forms swollen, grayish kernels on ears, reducing yield quality. Practice crop rotation, remove infected ears, and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce the spread of the disease. Use fungicides as necessary. Northern Corn Leaf Blight (Exserohilum turcicum): A fungal disease causing long, grayish lesions on leaves, leading to reduced photosynthesis. Use resistant corn varieties, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, and practice crop rotation to reduce disease pressure.
Watermelon Watermelon thrives in warm climates with temperatures between 22°C and 30°C. It requires full sun and moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) for healthy growth. Watermelon prefers well-drained, sandy loam soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 6.8. The soil should be loose to allow for large root development and proper drainage. Powdery Mildew (Podosphaera xanthii): A fungal disease that causes white, powdery patches on leaves, affecting plant growth and fruit development. Use sulfur-based fungicides, space plants to improve airflow, and avoid excessive moisture on the leaves. Remove infected leaves and practice crop rotation. Cucumber Beetle (Acalymma vittatum): A pest that feeds on watermelon plants, transmitting diseases and causing leaf damage. Use row covers, apply insecticides like neem oil, and practice good field hygiene to control cucumber beetles.
Soybean Soybeans thrive in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. They require full sunlight and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) during the growing season. Soybeans grow best in well-drained, fertile loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 6.8. The soil should have good water retention without becoming waterlogged. Rust (Phakopsora pachyrhizi): A fungal disease that causes reddish-brown lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield. Use resistant soybean varieties, apply fungicides such as triazoles, and practice crop rotation to reduce disease incidence. Soybean Aphid (Aphis glycines): A pest that feeds on plant sap, causing stunted growth and reduced yield. Control aphids with insecticides like pyrethrins or neem oil, and use natural predators like ladybugs to manage aphid populations.
Chickpea Chickpeas grow best in warm climates with temperatures between 18°C and 30°C. They require full sunlight and moderate rainfall (400–600 mm) for optimal growth. Chickpeas thrive in well-drained, sandy loam soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be fertile, with good water retention and aeration. Ascochyta Blight (Ascochyta rabiei): A fungal disease that causes lesions on leaves and stems, leading to defoliation and yield loss. Use resistant chickpea varieties, apply fungicides like tebuconazole, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plant material immediately to reduce disease spread. Root Rot (Fusarium spp.): A fungal disease that causes wilting and decay of roots, leading to stunted growth and plant death. Ensure good drainage, practice crop rotation, and use resistant varieties. Avoid excessive irrigation and remove infected plants to reduce disease spread.
Apple Apples thrive in temperate climates with temperatures ranging from 18°C to 24°C. They require cold winters for dormancy and moderate rainfall (600–800 mm) during the growing season. Apples prefer well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0. The soil should be fertile with good organic matter content. Apple Scab (Venturia inaequalis): A fungal disease causing lesions on leaves and fruit, leading to reduced yield and fruit quality. Use resistant varieties, apply fungicides during wet weather, and practice proper pruning for good airflow. Remove fallen leaves and fruit to prevent spores from spreading. Powdery Mildew (Podosphaera leucotricha): A fungal disease that affects young shoots, leaves, and flowers, causing white powdery growth. Apply sulfur-based fungicides and practice proper spacing between trees for improved airflow. Remove affected parts promptly and avoid overhead irrigation.
Blueberry Blueberries thrive in cool climates, typically between 16°C to 22°C. They require acidic soil and prefer a moderate amount of rainfall (500–700 mm) during the growing season. Blueberries grow best in well-drained, acidic soils with a pH range of 4.5 to 5.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter and moist but not waterlogged. Botrytis Blight (Botrytis cinerea): A fungal disease that causes gray mold on berries, flowers, and leaves. Use fungicides like thiophanate-methyl, practice good spacing between plants for airflow, and remove infected plant parts. Avoid overhead watering. Mummy Berry (Monilinia vaccinii-corymbosi): A fungal disease that causes premature berry drop and shriveled fruit. Remove infected fruit and debris from the ground, apply fungicides during bloom, and avoid overhead irrigation to prevent the spread of spores.
Cherry Cherries grow best in temperate climates with temperatures ranging from 18°C to 24°C. They require cold winters for dormancy and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm). Cherries prefer well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be fertile and well-aerated to promote healthy root growth. Cherry Leaf Spot (Blumeriella jaapii): A fungal disease causing purple or reddish spots on leaves, leading to premature defoliation. Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, prune trees for good airflow, and remove infected leaves. Practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen buildup. Brown Rot (Monilinia laxa): A fungal disease that causes fruit rot, leading to soft, mushy cherries. Remove infected fruit, apply fungicides, and practice proper sanitation. Prune trees to improve air circulation around the fruit.
Corn Corn grows best in warm climates with temperatures between 18°C and 30°C. It requires full sunlight and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) throughout the growing season. Corn prefers well-drained, fertile, loamy soils with a pH range of 5.8 to 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter to support robust growth. Corn Smut (Ustilago maydis): A fungal disease that forms swollen, grayish kernels on ears, reducing yield quality. Practice crop rotation, remove infected ears, and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce the spread of the disease. Use fungicides as necessary. Northern Corn Leaf Blight (Exserohilum turcicum): A fungal disease causing grayish lesions on leaves, leading to reduced photosynthesis. Use resistant corn varieties, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, and practice crop rotation to reduce disease pressure.
Grape Grapes grow best in temperate climates with temperatures between 15°C and 30°C. They require a dry growing season and full sunlight to produce high-quality fruit. Grapes prefer well-drained, sandy loam or clay loam soils with a pH range of 5.5 to 7.0. The soil should have good organic matter content and moisture retention. Powdery Mildew (Erysiphe necator): A fungal disease that causes white, powdery growth on leaves, stems, and fruit. Apply sulfur-based fungicides, practice proper spacing between vines for airflow, and avoid wetting the foliage. Remove infected leaves and fruit promptly. Downy Mildew (Plasmopara viticola): A fungal disease causing yellowish lesions on leaves and fruit rot. Apply copper-based fungicides, practice proper vineyard management, and remove infected plant material. Use drip irrigation to avoid wetting the leaves.
Orange Oranges grow best in subtropical to tropical climates, with temperatures ranging from 25°C to 35°C. They require full sunlight and moderate rainfall (500–800 mm) during the growing season. Oranges prefer well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good water retention. Citrus Canker (Xanthomonas axonopodis): A bacterial disease that causes lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, leading to fruit drop. Use resistant varieties, apply copper-based bactericides, and remove infected plant material. Avoid overhead irrigation and improve airflow around trees. Greening (Huanglongbing): A bacterial disease that causes yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and misshapen fruit. Remove infected trees, use insecticides to control vector insects, and practice good orchard sanitation to prevent the spread of the disease.
Peach Peaches grow best in temperate climates with temperatures between 18°C and 24°C. They require a cold winter for dormancy and moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) during the growing season. Peaches prefer well-drained, fertile, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0. The soil should be rich in organic matter and well-aerated for healthy root development. Peach Leaf Curl (Taphrina deformans): A fungal disease that causes distorted and curled leaves. Apply fungicides like copper sulfate, prune trees to improve airflow, and remove infected leaves to reduce fungal spread. Brown Rot (Monilinia fructicola): A fungal disease that causes soft, rotten fruit and affects flowers. Remove infected fruit, apply fungicides during bloom, and ensure proper orchard sanitation. Prune trees for better air circulation.
Raspberry Raspberries thrive in temperate climates with temperatures between 18°C and 24°C. They require moderate rainfall (500–700 mm) during the growing season. Raspberries prefer well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 5.6 to 6.5. The soil should be fertile and rich in organic matter. Gray Mold (Botrytis cinerea): A fungal disease that causes gray mold to form on berries, leading to fruit rot. Apply fungicides, remove infected fruit and debris, and avoid overhead watering to prevent the spread of the disease. Raspberry Rust (Puccinia rubi): A fungal disease that causes yellowish spots on leaves and reduces plant vigor. Prune and dispose of infected canes, apply fungicides, and maintain good plant spacing to improve airflow and reduce humidity around plants.
Squash Squash thrives in warm climates with temperatures between 20°C and 30°C. They require full sunlight and consistent rainfall (500–700 mm) or irrigation during the growing season. Squash prefers well-drained, loamy soils with a pH range of 6.0 to 6.8. The soil should be rich in organic matter and able to retain moisture without becoming waterlogged. Powdery Mildew (Podosphaera xanthii): A fungal disease that causes white, powdery growth on leaves, stems, and fruit. Use fungicides like sulfur or potassium bicarbonate, practice proper spacing between plants, and avoid overhead irrigation. Remove infected plant material promptly. Downy Mildew (Pseudoperonospora cubensis): A fungal disease causing yellowish spots on leaves, leading to premature leaf drop. Apply copper-based fungicides, maintain proper spacing for good air circulation, and practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen buildup.
Strawberry Strawberries grow best in temperate climates with temperatures ranging from 15°C to 25°C. They require consistent rainfall (500–700 mm) or irrigation throughout the growing season. Strawberries prefer well-drained, sandy loam soils with a pH range of 5.5 to 6.5. The soil should be rich in organic matter and have good moisture retention without becoming waterlogged. Gray Mold (Botrytis cinerea): A fungal disease that causes grayish mold on fruit, leading to fruit rot and reduced shelf life. Apply fungicides like captan or thiophanate-methyl, remove infected fruit and leaves, and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce humidity around plants. Powdery Mildew (Sphaerotheca macularis): A fungal disease that causes white, powdery spots on leaves, petioles, and fruit, stunting plant growth. Apply sulfur-based fungicides, practice good crop rotation, and ensure proper spacing between plants to reduce moisture accumulation.
